abstract.p: Discovery of skull of "River-bed" race of man near Corwen.

opener.placeName: R. S. Evans Esq, | Belvedere Park, Lessness Heath | Kent.

div.p: I just write you a line about the skeletons in the Cave at Perth y chwari near Corwen, because I have lighted on a fact of considerable ethnological value. The human skulls are indisputably of the River-bed type (of Huxley), the tibiæ are strongly platycnemic, and thus the bandy-legged-ness of the River-bed race is established. The bandy-legged race occurs in Algeria, S. France, & Spain, as well as in the laterite of India (.— Last year Dr Oldham sent me a scrap big enough to swear by.) and now must be extended to Britain. I believe that once they occupied a large portion of Europe. Busk and I are laying our heads together, and I think that we shall make something out of the investigation. At Easter I am to have another dig in Denbigh, and after that the Craven caves are in hand as you will see by the enclosed.
Wishing you a happy new year, I am Dear Sir | Yours truly | W. Boyd Dawkins

div.note: The year is established by the relationship between this letter and the letter from W. B. Dawkins, 19 October 1869 (Correspondence vol. 17). Dawkins must have written ‘1869’ in error.
Robert Speke Evans was Dawkins’s father-in-law.
Thomas Henry Huxley had noticed common features in prehistoric skulls found mainly in river-bed sites in Britain and Ireland (T. H. Huxley 1862).
George Busk and Dawkins described the human remains at Perthichwareu in the Journal of the Ethnological Society (Dawkins and Busk 1870).

The Craven caves are near Settle, North Yorkshire. The enclosure has not been found, but probably related to the formation of a committee to undertake the exploration of the caves, beginning with the Victoria Cave; Dawkins made a preliminary report in Nature, 21 April 1870, pp. 628–9. On Dawkins’s research on the platycnemic bones, see also Lucas 2007.
